title: Will California voters approve Proposition 16 (Repeal Proposition 209 Affirmative Action Amendment)?
preds: CA has a strong support for minority groups.  Woke culture.
This survey puts Prop 16 ahead 53% to 47%. Now I don't know what to think. https://capitolweekly.net/an-early-voting-survey-of-the-ballot-propositions/
This survey puts Prop 16 ahead 53% to 47%. Now I don't know what to think. https://capitolweekly.net/an-early-voting-survey-of-the-ballot-propositions/
Paradigm shift. Rowing faster in the opposite direction.

Update my forecast based on more detailed polling data [1].  While the yes-no are 31 and 47%, there is a large number of undecided (22%).  More interesting (and revealing) information is that while the moderates and conservatives are overwhelmingly against this proposition, only 46% of the liberals (and also 46% for the Democrats) are for it.  So it appears that affirmative is not as favored by the liberals as commonly believed.   Note that Washington state (another liberal state) rejected a referendum for the repeal of the banning of affirmative action in 2019. I am reducing the probability from my previous forecast.   [1]  https://www.ppic.org/wp-content/uploads/crosstabs-likely-voters-0920.pdf
This does not as likley to pass as it once did.

Polls show only 31% for Proposition 16, and 47% against [1].  That means more voters are in favor of banning affirmative action as stated in Proposition 209.  Proposition 209 was passed with 55%.  Despite California is a very liberal state and affirmative action is one of the pet project of the liberals, the banning of affirmative action appears to be still in favor by the current voters.   Part of the problem is due to the nature of "affirmative action".  Proposition 209 states that California "shall not discriminate against, or grant preferential treatment to, any individual or group on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in the operation of public employment, public education, or public contracting".  The wording says it is against discrimination.  What is wrong with that? Indeed, quoting from Ballotpedia [2]: "A no vote [on Proposition 16] opposes this constitutional amendment, thereby keeping Proposition 209 (1996), which stated that the government and public institutions cannot discriminate against or grant preferential treatment to persons on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public employment, public education, and public contracting".  Again, a no vote on Proposition 16 means you are for discrimination. I don't know how much of the wording affects the polls.  But it is definitely confusing, by the nature of affirmative action.  It is unlikely that this proposition will pass. [1]  https://abc7news.com/whats-prop-16-what-is-ca-propostion-california-2020-polls/6439595/
[2]  https://ballotpedia.org/California_Proposition_16,_Repeal_Proposition_209_Affirmative_Action_Amendment_(2020)

Polling indicates the Proposition will not pass, but the campaign supporting the proposition has a lot more funding, and it is likely that undecideds will swing towards voting 'Yes' - in the majority of propositions in California the 'Yes' side wins. Endorsements for the 'Yes' side are a lot stronger, leading Democrats including Joe Biden's running mate Kamala Harris. That being said, the 'Yes' side has a long distance to catch up - ballotpedia has them down by 10 points and even if the undecideds swing 2/3 towards 'Yes', they would still be losing by 52/48. It may be a close vote but in my view the most likely outcome is still a 'No' vote.
Heading toward the crowd on this one. Poorly worded Preposition in an election overshadowed by other chioces.
people will misunderstand the proposition due to poor wording
PPIC poll shows weaker than expected support for Affirmative Action Amendment. [1]  [1] https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-09-16/california-proposition-16-ppic-affirmative-action-poll
Staying the same. This will pass.
I'm just going with crowd forecast.  I have no idea.

Originally read this and thought it strange that everyone was so in favor of discrimination, but further research shows that, in actuality, this is phrased very much from the viewpoint of affirmative action and diversity initiatives, which makes much more sense. Current political climate supports such a change, especially in a state like CA, and the wording on the ballot is compelling to say the least (i.e. calling it "Allow Diversity as a Factor in Public Employment, Education, and Contracting Decisions. Legislative Constitutional Amendment"). I mean, what honest Californian would vote against diversity? I think it will pass, though I am a little worried how it may be used in future legislation and rulings given it says nothing about the negative discrimination that could occur. Could this allow someone to be fired or not hired based on race or sexual orientation or some other characteristic? If anyone knows I'd love to hear it.
The climate is ripe for this to pass with overwhelming support.
Should put more effort into this one

Being the "inside view" as a Californian and one of those people who digs into propositions, this rings of Props that pass.
Big name backing, lots of funding. Just ask yourself how SF, LA and San  Diego will vote and that is your answer. The only doubt comes in the verbiage, which is intentionally confusing.  This will be useful later: https://www.kqed.org/elections/

Really recommend looking at @benjuliano1 for insight as to the base rate for this question. 55% implied base rate is well above the crowd forecast right now (28%) and that surprises me, for a variety of reasons.  First, California is a very liberal state and many of the influential democrats in California have supported this bill. Second, given that this is occurring in a presidential election in a very polarized environment, I can imagine a lot of voters voting for this as an implicitly anti-Trump vote.  I would like to make a strong prediction, but I see no polling on this question online so it's hard to take a strong stand. In addition, from my skim of the wikipedia article it seems like polling on questions regarding affirmative action largely depends on how the question is phrased so I wouldn't read to much into that.

Our base rate should be 55 percent. That’s the percentage of ballot measures that California voters have approved over the past ten years. Californians have a mixed record with affirmative action but not one that qualifies as establishing any significant history. Voters in the state have only considered such questions twice in 1996 and 2003 respectively. [1][2] Context will be important here. Both of California’s senators, Diane Fienstein and vice presidential hopeful Kamala Harris among a number of others have backed the reinstatement of affirmative action. [3] Harris is a popular figure in the state and the referendum will in some way function as her final test as a United States Senator - at least before the November election. Most significantly, the vote comes during a time of heightened racial consciousness for many people and this will undoubtedly factor in the decisions of many voters. I’m going slightly higher than the base rate on this but don’t want to go too high without more solid evidence which is proving harder to come by. 61 percent - above ‘Chances About Even’ but not quite ‘Probable’. [1]https://ballotpedia.org/California_Proposition_209,_Affirmative_Action_Initiative_(1996)
[2]https://ballotpedia.org/California_Proposition_54,_Prohibit_State_Classification_Based_on_Race_in_Education,_Employment,_and_Contracting_Initiative_(October_2003)
[3]https://www.politico.com/interactives/2020/california-november-ballot/#section-2

I'll have to watch this one, I'm afraid.  Referenda are a terrible idea, and California is California.  The combination begs for, and has often resulted in, incoherent policymaking, frequently inadvertent.  This will cut cruelly into my nap time.
This repeal will likely confuse a lot of people, but I am hoping it fails with my forecast. PS the title incorrectly cites Prop 205, it should read Prop 209.
